questions.question: In ADHD group dynamics, what is the primary therapeutic benefit of 'Universalization'?
options: The reduction of shame through the realization that one's struggles are shared by others.
The process of teaching ADHD clients to act like neurotypical individuals in social settings.
A method for standardized medication management across a large population.
The ability to generalize one specific skill to every area of life simultaneously.
questions.explanation: Universalization is a powerful group dynamic where members realize they are 'not the only ones,' which significantly reduces the toxic shame often associated with ADHD.

questions.question: When applying the T.H.R.I.V.E. Methodâ„¢ to curriculum design, what does 'Environmental Scaffolding' (the 'E') refer to in a group context?
options: The physical layout of the coaching office.
Providing external structures, such as shared digital planners or body doubling sessions, to support executive function.
Encouraging clients to quit their jobs to find ADHD-friendly environments.
The use of white noise machines during group sessions.
questions.explanation: Environmental Scaffolding involves creating external supports (tech, tools, or social structures) that compensate for internal executive function deficits.

questions.question: A participant in your ADHD group is 'monopolizing' the conversation and going down a 'rabbit hole.' According to Lesson 3, what is the most neuro-inclusive facilitation technique to use?
options: Firmly tell them to stop talking so others can have a turn.
Ignore the behavior and hope other participants intervene.
Use a 'Parking Lot' for off-topic ideas and implement a visual timer for all shares.
Mute their microphone immediately without explanation.
questions.explanation: Using a 'Parking Lot' validates the participant's contribution while maintaining the group's focus, and visual timers provide an objective boundary that reduces Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD).

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of the 'Intensive' workshop format (e.g., a 6-hour Saturday session) for the ADHD brain?
options: It allows for deeper hyperfocus and eliminates the 'startup cost' of re-engaging with the topic weekly.
It is easier for ADHD clients to sit still for 6 hours than for 1 hour.
It requires less preparation from the facilitator.
It is the only format that allows for medication adjustments.
questions.explanation: Intensives leverage the ADHD tendency for hyperfocus and reduce the executive function load required to 'gear up' for multiple weekly sessions.

questions.question: In Virtual Group Management (Lesson 5), 'Tech Scaffolding' includes which of the following?
options: Requiring participants to buy the most expensive laptop available.
Automated 'nudge' notifications (SMS/Email) sent 15 minutes before a session starts.
Using complex software that requires 10 hours of training to use.
Prohibiting the use of cameras during sessions.
questions.explanation: Tech scaffolding involves using automation to support memory and transitions, such as 'just-in-time' reminders for sessions.

questions.question: According to the 'Community Maturity Model' in Lesson 6, what characterizes a 'Sustainable' peer support community?
options: The facilitator must answer every single post personally.
Members begin to provide peer-to-peer support and 'body doubling' without constant facilitator prompting.
The group is closed to new members forever.
The community relies entirely on a single social media platform's algorithm.
questions.explanation: Sustainability is achieved when the community develops its own momentum and members support one another, reducing the facilitator's 'bottleneck' role.

questions.question: When pricing an ADHD group program, the 'Group Multiplier' suggests your total revenue per session should ideally be:
options: Equal to your individual 1-on-1 hourly rate.
At least 2x to 3x your individual hourly rate to account for increased facilitation energy and logistics.
Lower than your individual rate to make it affordable for everyone.
Based entirely on the number of handouts provided.
questions.explanation: To be a sustainable business model, group programs should generate higher hourly revenue (2x-3x) than 1-on-1 work to cover the higher administrative and energy costs of group management.

questions.question: Which metric is most critical for 'Data-Driven Program Iteration' (Lesson 8) in an ADHD context?
options: The number of likes on the program's Instagram page.
The 'Completion Rate' of weekly homework assignments versus the 'Transformation Rate' of core symptoms.
The facilitator's personal feelings about the group.
How many participants showed up for the first session only.
questions.explanation: Measuring the gap between assignment completion and actual symptom improvement helps facilitators refine the 'scaffolding' provided in the curriculum.

questions.question: The '10-2 Rule' in ADHD facilitation refers to:
options: 10 minutes of teaching followed by 2 minutes of active processing or interaction.
10 participants and 2 facilitators.
Starting at 10:00 AM and ending at 2:00 PM.
10 pages of reading and 2 pages of writing.
questions.explanation: The 10-2 rule respects the ADHD attention span by breaking content into small chunks (10 mins) followed by immediate engagement (2 mins) to cement learning.

questions.question: In Lesson 7, what is the 'Rule of 12' regarding group size for deep-work ADHD transformation?
options: 12 is the minimum number of people needed for a group.
Groups larger than 12 often lead to decreased participation and increased 'social loafing' or overwhelm for ADHD members.
The program must last exactly 12 weeks.
Participants must be at least 12 years old.
questions.explanation: For deep, transformative work, a cap of 12 participants is often recommended to ensure everyone has 'air time' and to prevent the sensory/social overwhelm common in larger ADHD groups.
